#Text=1 .
#Text=Introduction

#Text=According to the recent disclosure of the World Bank , the total volume of people who are still struggling to meet basic needs was 3.4 billion in 2018 , which is almost half the world ’s population .
#Text=This demonstrates the magnitude of the challenge of worldwide poverty reduction and the significance of work in this field .
#Text=Various strategies and tools have been proposed to address this severe and serious issue .

#Text=Among these strategies and tools , the microfinance institution ( MFI ) , which distinguishes itself from traditional financial institutions , such as the commercial bank , by operating small loans to “ unbankable poor people and small businesses ” , is not only considered an effective way for the poor to manage their finances and take advantage of economic opportunities while managing risks , but also an important way to promote economic development , employment and growth , through the financial support of small businesses .

#Text=The MFI has attracted tremendous interest from both practitioners and academic researchers for its significant role in poverty reduction , by bridging the gap between formal financial institutions and low-income groups or individuals .
#Text=In order to make full use of MFIs in poverty reduction , various
#Text=MFIs have been set up all over the world since the 1970s , especially in developing countries and regions .
#Text=To date , in terms of amount of customers served , the MFI is poised to become the largest banking market in the world .
#Text=At the same time , MFIs are also suffering from fierce competition and rapid changes in the business environment .
#Text=It is hard to sustain their success into the future in an increasingly complex business climate .
#Text=Given the significant role of MFIs in poverty reduction , it is important to operate MFIs effectively and efficiently to achieve sustainable financial development .
#Text=It is generally believed that it is better not to have any MFIs than to have unsustainable ones .
#Text=Therefore , it is important to scientifically evaluate the sustainability of MFIs in the complex business environment .
#Text=Generally , sustainability is the ability to meet the needs of the present without compromising future generations .
#Text=It is composed of three pillars : environmental , economic , and social .
#Text=However , given the features of MFIs , the definition of sustainability is a little different in the early related literature .
#Text=The sustainability definition of MFIs has focused on two pillars .
#Text=One is financial ( economic ) sustainability .
#Text=This emphasizes the financial self-sufficiency of MFIs , and a reduction in reliance on donor funds .
#Text=The other is social sustainability , which focuses on social outreach .

#Text=In recent years , in addition to social and financial sustainability , more and more studies have paid attention to the environmental sustainability of MFIs , analyzing the green environment performance of MFIs .
#Text=A financially sustainable MFI is required , in order to achieve social and environmental sustainability .
#Text=Therefore , this paper focuses on evaluating the financial sustainability of MFIs .
#Text=In other words , we attempt to evaluate the financial self-sufficiency of MFIs .
#Text=To evaluate the financial sustainability of MFIs , previous studies have adopted accounting ratios and corporate governance factors as criteria .
#Text=However , as well as the traditional financial system , MFIs are also a part of the social economy system , shown in
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=.

#Text=More and more research has recognized that the performance of MFIs is not only influenced by internal factors , but also impacted by their external macro-environment , including the finance sector environment , macro-economic environment , and information technology environment .

#Text=Meanwhile , given the negative influence of failed MFIs , some mathematical models have been proposed for evaluating the financial sustainability of MFIs , such as the order preference by similarity to ideal solution ( TOPSIS ) , and the data envelopment analysis operating frontiers model ( DEA-OF ) , .
#Text=Prior studies have established a solid foundation for evaluating the financial sustainability of MFIs .

#Text=However , to the best of our knowledge , the majority of prior studies evaluating the financial sustainability of MFIs adopted accounting ratios and corporate governance factors as criteria , in the context of one country .
#Text=Macro-environmental factors have received little attention to date .

#Text=There has been no study evaluating the financial sustainability of MFIs integrating this many factors as criteria , especially ones accounting for the interaction between MFIs and their external operating environment .
#Text=In practical terms , this interaction includes the externality of MFIs to their environment and the influence of uncontrollable environmental factors on the financial sustainability of MFIs .

#Text=It should be noted that neglect of macro-environmental factors may lead to an overestimation of the financial sustainability score of MFIs , and have implications for managerial decision making , which should contribute to effective MFI performance .
